content.title: Omicron and the Office: Your Questions, Answered
content.description: We cover how the pandemic has affected the workplace. Here's what we are hearing.
content.author: Emma Goldberg and Lauren Hirsch

content.title: How Corporate America Has Changed After the Capitol Attack
content.description: Business leaders promised a reckoning after the Jan. 6 riots. They’ve altered some practices, and returned to others.
content.author: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

content.title: Cases Rise, Criticism Mounts, but Ships Keep Cruising
content.description: One day after the C.D.C. advised against all travel on cruise ships, thousands of cruisers partied like it was 2019. But worries about onboard policies — and frustration over quarantines — is rising.
content.author: Ceylan Yeginsu

content.title: Starbucks union workers near Buffalo walk out over Covid concerns.
content.description: The walkout, involving about half a dozen employees, is planned to last the rest of the week.
content.author: Emma Goldberg

content.title: Federal Labor Officials Claim New York Times Violated Workplace Law
content.description: The National Labor Relations Board alleges that Times management wrongly prevented some employees from showing support for a union, a claim the paper denied.
content.author: Katie Robertson

content.title: F.B.I. Arrests Man Accused of Stealing Unpublished Book Manuscripts
content.description: Filippo Bernardini, an Italian citizen who worked in publishing, was charged with wire fraud and identity theft for a scheme that prosecutors said affected hundreds of people over five or more years.
content.author: Elizabeth A. Harris

content.title: Slate’s Top Editor Leaves After a Three-Year Run
content.description: Jared Hohlt, who made his reputation at New York magazine, led the publication’s newsroom during a difficult period for digital media.
content.author: Marc Tracy

content.title: Fed officials discussed raising rates sooner and faster in 2022.
content.description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting show that officials are contemplating when and how quickly to lift interest rates.
content.author: Jeanna Smialek

content.title: The Oscars Want Crowd-Pleasers, but Where Are the Crowds?
content.description: As contenders like “West Side Story” and “Belfast” struggle for audiences, can a blockbuster like “Spider-Man: No Way Home” swing into the Oscar race?
content.author: Kyle Buchanan

content.title: Barbie and Balmain Want to Make Toys the Next Big Fashion Frontier
content.description: The first high-fashion collaboration of the year is here, and it’s surprisingly good.
content.author: Vanessa Friedman

content.title: Cases Rise, Criticism Mounts, but Ships Keep Cruising
content.description: One day after the C.D.C. advised against all travel on cruise ships, thousands of cruisers partied like it was 2019. But worries about onboard policies — and frustration over quarantines — is rising.
content.author: Ceylan Yeginsu

content.title: Weekly Health Quiz: Stress, Omicron and Weight Training
content.description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content.author: Toby Bilanow

content.title: Hedgehogs Are a Source of Drug-Resistant Bacteria, Study Finds
content.description: Scientists chart how a battle between fungus and bacteria living on the skin of hedgehogs led to the emergence of a strain of MRSA that can infect cows and humans.
content.author: Andrew Jacobs

content.title: India’s Rising Omicron Wave Brings a Grim Sense of Déjà Vu
content.description: Just months after Delta fueled hospital failures and funeral pyres, India’s leaders again offer a mixed message: Their political rallies are packed even as they order curfews and work closures.
content.author: Mujib Mashal and Karan Deep Singh

content.title: Biden Administration to Increase Supply of ‘Game Changer’ Pfizer Pill
content.description: President Biden announced that his administration would double its order of Pfizer’s scarce Covid-19 antiviral drug, which has been shown to reduce hospitalizations.
content.author: Noah Weiland and Rebecca Robbins

content.title: ‘We May Need Even More’: Biden Doubles Pfizer’s Covid Pills Order
content.description: President Biden announced that the United States government doubled its order for Pfizer’s Covid pills, bringing the total order to 20 million treatment courses.
content.author: The Associated Press

content.title: The Epic Rise and Fall of Elizabeth Holmes
content.description: In Silicon Valley’s world of make-believe, the philosophy of “fake it until you make it” finally gets its comeuppance.
content.author: David Streitfeld

content.title: Elizabeth Holmes is found guilty of four counts of fraud.
content.description: The case against the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos came to symbolize the pitfalls of Silicon Valley’s culture of hustle and hype.
content.author: Erin Griffith and Erin Woo

content.title: With no way to identify Omicron and Delta patients, treatment decisions are vexing doctors.
content.description: There is no approved test to determine which variant each patient has, and that makes treatment nearly impossible to tailor as supplies run low.
content.author: Christina Jewett

content.title: Exercising to Slim Down? Try Getting Bigger.
content.description: It’s high time for women to reclaim the real strength behind exercise.
content.author: Danielle Friedman

content.title: F.B.I. Arrests Man Accused of Stealing Unpublished Book Manuscripts
content.description: Filippo Bernardini, an Italian citizen who worked in publishing, was charged with wire fraud and identity theft for a scheme that prosecutors said affected hundreds of people over five or more years.
content.author: Elizabeth A. Harris

content.title: Dr. Ronald Weinstein, Telepathology Pioneer, Dies at 83
content.description: Decades ago, he demonstrated that cancer could be diagnosed remotely. It was a pivotal step in the evolution of telemedicine.
content.author: Neil Genzlinger

content.title: OpenSea valued at $13.3 billion in new round of venture funding.
content.description: The blockchain start-up, one of the most talked about in Silicon Valley, said on Tuesday that had it raised $300 million in new venture capital.
content.author: Mike Isaac

content.title: Election Falsehoods Surged on Podcasts Before Capitol Riots, Researchers Find
content.description: A new study analyzed nearly 1,500 episodes, showing the extent to which podcasts pushed misinformation about voter fraud.
content.author: Stuart A. Thompson

content.title: A mistrial was declared for three counts in the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
content.description: The three hung counts were related to investments from three Theranos investors who testified that Ms. Holmes misled them.
content.author: Erin Woo

content.title: 5G cellular service will go forward as U.S. reaches deal with carriers.
content.description: Transportation regulators had clashed with AT&T and Verizon, saying the new technology posed a security risk.
content.author: David McCabe

content.title: What We Got Wrong About Tech
content.description: Looking back at tech misjudgments so we can better look ahead.
content.author: Shira Ovide

content.title: Tesla opens a dealership in Xinjiang, drawing accusations it’s helping China ‘cover up genocide.’
content.description: Senator Marco Rubio criticized the electric carmaker for opening the outlet in a region where China has been accused of targeting Muslims.
content.author: Jack Ewing

content.title: Toyota Topped G.M. in U.S. Car Sales in 2021, a First for a Foreign Automaker
content.description: After struggling to produce cars because of a global computer chip shortage, automakers are trying to move quickly to making electric vehicles.
content.author: Neal E. Boudette

content.title: Silicon Valley Can’t Escape Elizabeth Holmes
content.description: Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, wasn’t a creature of Silicon Valley, or so the refrain went. But her fraud trial showed otherwise.
content.author: Erin Griffith

content.title: Mining of Lithium, Key to the Climate Fight, Faces New Scrutiny in Chile
content.description: Politicians have called for a pause in new mining contracts for lithium, which is in high demand for electric car batteries but is at the heart of a debate in Chile over mines, water rights and inequality.
content.author: John Bartlett

content.title: Emerging Data Raise Questions About Antigen Tests and Nasal Swabs
content.description: A new study adds to evidence that common rapid tests may fail to detect some Omicron cases in the first days of infection.
content.author: Emily Anthes and Christina Jewett

content.title: Health Risks of Smoke and Ozone Rise in the West as Wildfires Worsen
content.description: Simultaneous high levels of the two pollutants, which harm human health, are occurring with increasing frequency, researchers say.
content.author: Henry Fountain

content.title: Dr. Ronald Weinstein, Telepathology Pioneer, Dies at 83
content.description: Decades ago, he demonstrated that cancer could be diagnosed remotely. It was a pivotal step in the evolution of telemedicine.
content.author: Neil Genzlinger

content.title: India’s Rising Omicron Wave Brings a Grim Sense of Déjà Vu
content.description: Just months after Delta fueled hospital failures and funeral pyres, India’s leaders again offer a mixed message: Their political rallies are packed even as they order curfews and work closures.
content.author: Mujib Mashal and Karan Deep Singh

content.title: This Vast Wildfire Lab Is Helping Foresters Prepare for a Hotter Planet
content.description: When the Bootleg fire tore through a nature reserve in Oregon this summer, the destruction varied in different areas. Researchers say forest management methods, including controlled burns, were a big factor.
content.author: Henry Fountain

content.title: In Omicron Hot Spots, Hospitals Fill Up, but I.C.U.s May Not
content.description: Covid hospitalizations are surging, but a smaller proportion of cases is severe compared with previous waves. With staff shortages, some hospitals are still in crisis.
content.author: Emily Anthes and Azeen Ghorayshi

content.title: By weight, how much of you is carbon?
content.description: Answer this question to learn a bit about what you’re made of.
content.author: Kenneth Chang

content.title: Considering Bone or Joint Surgery? You May Not Need It.
content.description: For many common problems of the knee, hip, shoulder, spine and wrist, nonsurgical options may be just as good.
content.author: Nicholas Bakalar

content.title: Did a Meteor Explode Over Pittsburgh?
content.description: A meteor likely either “exploded or vaporized” over the city on Saturday, a meteorologist said, setting off a strong vibration that one resident likened to a “shock wave.”
content.author: Azi Paybarah

content.title: Kyrie Irving returns to the court after refusing to be vaccinated.
content.description: Irving declined to be vaccinated for Covid-19 before the season, making him ineligible to play in New York City because of a local vaccine mandate at sports arenas that went into effect in September.
content.author: Sopan Deb

content.title: Australia Denies Entry to Novak Djokovic Over Vaccine Exemption
content.description: Novak Djokovic, the world’s No. 1-ranked men’s tennis player, was told to leave Australia after a 12-hour standoff with government officials over questions about the evidence supporting a medical exemption from a Covid-19 vaccine.
content.author: Reuters

content.title: Skepticism and anger greet Novak Djokovic’s vaccine exemption.
content.description: Some Australians reacted with fury at the announcement from the world’s No. 1 male tennis player, the sport’s most prominent vaccination skeptic.
content.author: Matthew Futterman and Yan Zhuang

content.title: Skepticism Greets Novak Djokovic’s Vaccine Exemption
content.description: The world No. 1 received an exemption to a rule that players be vaccinated to play in the Australian Open. Government officials said they had the power to overturn it.
content.author: Matthew Futterman

content.title: 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics: Answers to Some Big Questions
content.description: How will the Olympics deal with the coronavirus? What happens if athletes protest China? Will there be boycotts? Here’s what we know.
content.author: Andrew Keh

content.title: Kathy Flores, Pathbreaking Women’s Rugby Coach, Dies at 66
content.description: She was a gifted player and exacting coach who pushed for recognition of women in a historically male-dominated sport.
content.author: Annabelle Williams

content.title: N.F.L.’s Week 18 Will Sort Playoff Berths
content.description: In the N.F.C., Green Bay has clinched the bye, but a divisional race and a wild-card spot are still up for grabs. In the A.F.C., things are messier.
content.author: Victor Mather

content.title: Djokovic is granted a medical exemption to play in the Australian Open.
content.description: The top-ranked player in men’s tennis revealed his plans in a post on his Instagram account.
content.author: Andrew Das

content.title: The Field Is Crowded, but Mostly Behind South Carolina
content.description: Increasing parity in women’s college basketball, and a slew of coronavirus interruptions, makes the regular season less predictable. But the Gamecocks still stand out.
content.author: Natalie Weiner

content.title: ‘Fuel to Her Fire’: A Rising Basketball Star Thrives When You Doubt Her
content.description: Diamond Johnson is making a name for herself at North Carolina State after being snubbed for a major high school honor.
content.author: Jonathan Abrams

content.title: Watch Live: Senators Speak on Anniversary of Capitol Riot
content.description: Senators deliver floor speeches one year after a deadly attack on the U.S. Capitol by supporters of Donald J. Trump who tried to disrupt the formal certification of President Biden’s electoral victory.
content.author: The Associated Press

content.title: Here is a schedule of events commemorating the Jan. 6 attack.
content.description: Speeches by President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris are part of the events to mark the anniversary of the attack on the Capitol.
content.author: The New York Times

content.title: Hochul’s Speech Is a Road Map to the Campaign That Lies Ahead
content.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul sought to exude decisiveness in crisis, previewing her efforts to run as the steady-hand candidate as she seeks her first full term.
content.author: Katie Glueck

content.title: A Fed Official’s 2020 Trade Drew Outcry. It Went Further Than First Disclosed.
content.description: Corrected disclosures show that Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida sold a stock fund, then swiftly repurchased it before a big Fed announcement.
content.author: Jeanna Smialek

content.title: One Year Later, Congress Weighs How to Memorialize Jan. 6 at the Capitol
content.description: In a building that is both a legislative body and a living museum, lawmakers are grappling with how to commemorate an attack whose victims cannot agree on the basic facts of the day.
content.author: Emily Cochrane

content.title: A Year Later, Jan. 6 Becomes Just Another Wedge in a Divided Nation
content.description: The nearly universal outrage after the assault on the Capitol has reverted to separate blue and red realities, and former President Donald J. Trump has remained the dominant force in his party.
content.author: Peter Baker

content.title: Federal Prisons Director Is Resigning After Rocky Tenure
content.description: Michael Carvajal took over the Bureau of Prisons in February 2020, just as the coronavirus began to sweep through the nation’s prisons.
content.author: Katie Benner

content.title: How Many Americans Support Political Violence?
content.description: Probably a lot fewer than you’ve been led to believe, but more than enough to make you nervous.
content.author: Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam

content.title: For C.D.C.’s Walensky, a Steep Learning Curve on Messaging
content.description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has stumbled in explaining her policy decisions.
content.author: Sharon LaFraniere, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
